issues.title: Cooling System Failures
issues.symptoms: Overheating, coolant leaks, temperature gauge pegged high, steam from engine bay, heater blowing cold
issues.description: The E36 cooling system is notoriously fragile and one of the most critical maintenance items. BMW used plastic components that become brittle with heat cycles and age. The expansion tank, thermostat housing, water pump impeller, and radiator end tanks are all prone to failure. A cooling system failure can quickly lead to head gasket damage or a warped head.
fixes: Replace expansion tank every 60,000 miles or at first sign of cracking
Replace thermostat and housing (upgrade to aluminum housing available)
Install water pump with metal impeller (plastic impellers can shatter)
Replace radiator with aluminum or new OEM unit
Replace all coolant hoses during major service
Consider doing a full cooling system refresh preventatively

repairCosts.notes: Full refresh recommended. Replace all plastic components together.

issues.title: VANOS System Issues (M50TU/M52)
issues.symptoms: Rough idle, loss of low-end torque, engine rattle at startup, hesitation between 2500-3500 RPM
issues.description: The E36 with M50TU and M52 engines uses BMW's Single VANOS variable valve timing system. The VANOS unit's seals harden and fail over time, leading to oil leaks and loss of proper valve timing. The VANOS piston seals and the oil supply line seals are the most common failure points.
fixes: Replace VANOS seals with upgraded Viton seal kit
Replace VANOS oil line O-rings
Clean VANOS solenoid screen filter
For severe cases, rebuild or replace entire VANOS unit

repairCosts.notes: Single VANOS on M50TU/M52. Seal kit is most common fix.

issues.title: Rear Trailing Arm Bushing (RTAB) Failure
issues.symptoms: Clunking from rear over bumps, vague rear-end feel, rear tire wear on inside edge, visible bushing deterioration
issues.description: The rear trailing arm bushings on the E36 are a well-known weak point. These bushings support the rear suspension and when they wear out, they allow excessive movement of the rear wheels. This affects handling, causes accelerated tire wear, and can make the car feel loose or unpredictable in corners.
fixes: Replace with OEM rubber bushings (softer ride, will wear again)
Upgrade to polyurethane or Delrin bushings (longer lasting, slightly harsher)
Consider RTAB limiter kit to reduce deflection
Get an alignment after replacement
Check rear subframe mounts at the same time

repairCosts.notes: Budget for alignment after replacement. Both sides recommended.

issues.title: Window Regulator Failure
issues.symptoms: Window drops into door, grinding noise during operation, window moves slowly or crooked, clicking sounds
issues.description: E36 window regulators use plastic clips and guides that fail over time. When the clips break, the window can drop into the door panel. This is especially common on driver's side windows due to more frequent use.
fixes: Replace entire window regulator assembly
Some owners replace just the plastic clips (temporary fix)
Lubricate window tracks to reduce strain on regulators
Replace both front regulators at the same time

issues.title: Oil Leaks
issues.symptoms: Oil spots under car, burning oil smell, visible oil on engine, low oil level between changes
issues.description: E36s are known for developing oil leaks from several common locations. The valve cover gasket, oil filter housing gasket (OFHG), oil pan gasket, and rear main seal are all common leak points. The OFHG is particularly notorious and can leak onto the serpentine belt.
fixes: Replace valve cover gasket (easy DIY job)
Replace oil filter housing gasket (common and important)
Replace VANOS line O-rings (often done with OFHG)
Replace oil pan gasket (requires lifting engine slightly)
Rear main seal (labor-intensive, do with clutch replacement)

repairCosts.notes: Valve cover gasket is easiest. Oil filter housing and pan require more labor.

issues.title: Control Arm Bushings
issues.symptoms: Steering wheel vibration, clunking over bumps, pulling to one side, uneven front tire wear
issues.description: The E36 front suspension uses control arms with pressed-in bushings that wear over time. The lower control arm bushings are the most common failure point. Worn bushings cause imprecise steering, vibration, and accelerated tire wear.
fixes: Replace complete control arms (bushings are pressed in)
OEM bushings for stock feel, or polyurethane for performance
Consider M3 control arms for track use (different geometry)
Alignment is required after replacement
Inspect ball joints while control arms are out

repairCosts.notes: Replace in pairs. Alignment required after.

issues.title: Ignition System Failures
issues.symptoms: Misfires, rough idle, poor fuel economy, check engine light, hesitation under load
issues.description: The E36's ignition system components wear out and can cause running issues. The ignition coils, spark plugs, plug wires (on earlier models), and crankshaft position sensor are common failure points.
fixes: Replace spark plugs every 30,000-60,000 miles
Replace ignition coils if misfiring
Replace crankshaft position sensor (causes no-starts)
Check and replace camshaft position sensor if needed
Replace spark plug wires on earlier models

repairCosts.notes: Replace all coils and plugs together for best results.

diyGuides.title: Oil Change
diyGuides.description: Complete oil and filter change procedure for M50 and M52 engines.
steps: Warm up the engine for 2-3 minutes to thin the oil for better drainage.
Safely raise the front of the car and support on jack stands.
Locate the oil drain plug on the passenger side of the oil pan.
Position drain pan and remove the 17mm drain plug. Allow oil to drain completely (5-10 minutes).
Replace the copper crush washer on the drain plug.
Reinstall drain plug and torque to 18 ft-lbs (25 Nm).
The oil filter housing is on top of the engine - remove the cap with a 36mm socket or filter wrench.
Remove the old filter element and O-ring from the cap.
Install new filter element and lubricate the new O-ring with fresh oil.
Reinstall filter cap and torque to 25 ft-lbs (34 Nm).
Remove the oil fill cap and add 6.9 quarts (M50) or 6.5 quarts (M52) of 5W-40 or 0W-40 oil.
Check level with dipstick - add oil until it reaches the upper mark.
Start engine and check for leaks around drain plug and filter housing.
Recheck oil level after engine has run for a minute and settled.
tips: BMW E36s use a cartridge-style oil filter - never install the metal canister type.
Always replace the O-ring on the filter housing cap to prevent leaks.
The oil filter housing gasket is a common leak point - inspect while changing oil.

diyGuides.title: Valve Cover Gasket
diyGuides.description: Stop oil leaks with a new valve cover gasket - one of the easiest E36 repairs.
steps: Disconnect the negative battery terminal for safety.
Remove the cabin microfilter housing cover (4 clips) for better access.
Disconnect any electrical connectors on top of the valve cover (coil packs, etc).
Remove the oil fill cap.
Remove the 10mm valve cover bolts (15 bolts total) in a spiral pattern from outside to center.
Carefully lift the valve cover straight up - it may stick from the old gasket.
Clean all old gasket material from the valve cover and cylinder head mating surfaces.
Clean the spark plug tube seal areas thoroughly.
Install the new gasket onto the valve cover - it should snap into the groove.
Install new spark plug tube seals (often included with gasket kit).
Apply a small dab of RTV at the corners where the timing cover meets the head (optional but recommended).
Place valve cover back on the head, ensuring gasket is properly seated.
Install bolts finger-tight, then torque to 89 in-lbs (10 Nm) in a spiral pattern from center outward.
Reinstall oil cap, microfilter housing, and reconnect electrical connectors.
Reconnect battery and start engine to check for leaks.
tips: Do not overtighten valve cover bolts - the plastic cover can crack.
Replace the spark plug tube seals at the same time to prevent oil pooling around plugs.
Check the grommets on the valve cover bolts - replace if cracked or deteriorated.

diyGuides.title: Brake Pad Replacement
diyGuides.description: Front and rear brake pad replacement with rotor inspection.
tools: Brake caliper piston tool or C-clamp
steps: Loosen lug bolts while car is on the ground, then raise and secure on jack stands.
Remove wheel to access brake caliper.
Disconnect brake pad wear sensor if equipped (front driver side, rear passenger side).
Remove the two 7mm Allen caliper guide pin bolts from the rear of the caliper.
Swing the caliper up and support it - do not let it hang by the brake hose.
Remove old brake pads from the caliper bracket.
Inspect rotor for scoring, cracks, or minimum thickness. Replace if worn.
Clean caliper bracket pad contact points with wire brush.
Use piston tool or C-clamp to compress the caliper piston back into the housing.
Apply brake grease to the pad backing plates where they contact the caliper bracket.
Install new pads into the bracket - the pad with the wear sensor slot goes on the inner side.
Swing caliper back down over the new pads and reinstall guide pin bolts. Torque to 22 ft-lbs (30 Nm).
Reinstall brake pad wear sensor.
Reinstall wheel and torque lug bolts to 88 ft-lbs (120 Nm) in a star pattern.
Repeat for all four corners.
Before driving, pump the brake pedal several times until firm to seat the pads.
tips: Open the brake fluid reservoir cap when compressing pistons to prevent pressure buildup.
Clean rotors with brake cleaner to remove any oils before installing new pads.
Bed in new pads with 5-10 moderate stops from 30 mph to transfer pad material to rotors.

diyGuides.title: Cooling System Refresh
diyGuides.description: Replace expansion tank, thermostat, and water pump to prevent overheating failures.
steps: Allow engine to cool completely before beginning work.
Remove the fan shroud upper clips and expansion tank cap.
Using a 32mm wrench and fan holding tool, remove the fan clutch (LEFT-HAND THREAD - turn clockwise to loosen).
Remove the fan and shroud assembly together.
Drain coolant by opening the drain plug on the lower passenger side of the radiator.
Remove the expansion tank by disconnecting hoses and removing the mounting bolt.
Remove the two 10mm bolts from the thermostat housing and note the orientation of the thermostat.
Remove old thermostat and clean mating surfaces.
For water pump: Remove the four 10mm bolts from the water pump pulley.
Remove the three 10mm bolts holding the water pump to the block.
Scrape old gasket material from the block surface.
Install new water pump with new gasket and torque bolts to 7 ft-lbs (10 Nm).
Install new thermostat (jiggle valve at 12 o'clock position) with new gasket.
Install new expansion tank and connect all hoses.
Reinstall water pump pulley, fan clutch (LEFT-HAND THREAD - turn counter-clockwise to tighten), and shroud.
Close radiator drain and fill system with 50/50 BMW coolant mix.
Bleed system: Run engine with heater on full hot, cap off, until thermostat opens and level stabilizes.
Top off coolant and install expansion tank cap.
Check for leaks after engine reaches operating temperature.
tips: The fan clutch is LEFT-HAND THREADED - turn clockwise to remove.
Use a water pump with a metal impeller - plastic impellers can shatter.
Replace the thermostat housing with an aluminum version if the original plastic one shows any cracks.
Check all coolant hoses for cracks or soft spots while the system is apart.
